Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2011 05:56AM Lauriesh wrote: I have a couple favorite memories- My son was about 3 , and we used to fly a lot with our kids. On one flight there was a lot of turbulence, and the pilot was dropping us down, i suppose to lesson the turbulence, and my son started  yelling "oh we're going down, we're going down!" over and over. He was excited because he thought we were close to landing, but I felt bad for any nervous travelers that were thinking he was predicting that the end was near. After having two sons, my youngest was a girl.  She was tiny for her age, was like in the 5 % for her height, and 1 % for her weight  and I always dressed her in cute little pink dresses. One  day we were at the pediatrician's office, and there was another mom in the waiting room with a boy who was about 2 1/2, but about twice the size of my daughter. The mom kept saying how sweet and adorable my little girl was.   My daughter  was playing quietly on a little ride-on push toy, when this  boy comes up to her and trys to take the toy away from her. As he just grabs the handle, she shoves him (hard) with her right hand in his  chest and he goes flying backward, then starts crying. My daughter doesn't say anything, she just keeps riding.  The other mom looks horrified, so of course, I apologize to the mom, and explain that she has two older brothers, and is used to defending herself.  Secretly, I am  trying not  laugh, and I am thinking, "you go girl, don't let anyone push you around"  She is now 9, and is still feisty. Laurie

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2012 05:17AM - edited Apr 1, 2012 05:18AM by Lauriesh Whether it was a planning scan for rads or for reconstruction, it would be possible for mets to show up on a ct that doesn't use contrast. I had a nightmare ct scan done where the contrast instead of going through my port, popped out and sprayed the contrast into my chest. They couldn't get an iv in my arm, so they just ran the ct with no contrast.  While they couldn't get an accurate measurement of my liver mets, you could still clearly see them on the scan.  Also, my mets were very high up on my liver. When I had RFA done, they went in under my breast and through the ribs. so, even if they just scanned this lady's  chest area, liver mets could have been seen. Laurie

Posts.Content: Nov 26, 2013 12:32PM Lauriesh wrote: I agree that finding mets early has little benefit, in the long run, in terms of survival. Finding one small liver tumor and having a resection doesn't increase the chance of remaining Ned any longer than someone who had several large mets, did chemo and got to Ned. I remember reading somewhere that by the time a tumor can be seen on a scan it is already made up of over a million cells. All it takes is one of those cellS to survive and to multiply at another site. There is so much that is unknown about mets. In some women, the mets spread everywhere quickly, where with others, such as me, I had very large liver tumors ( one was 11 cm), but had not spread anywhere else, eventhough the cancer was in my blood, as my tumer markers had doubled when I was diagnosed. Er+ cancer likes the bones, but for some reason er- doesn't. Not saying that er- women never get bone mets, but it is not common. There are women who were diagnosed after me, with lower tumor volume in their liver, so their cancer was " caught early" , with the same cancer profile, who had resection who have already passed or are still living, but quickly had a recurrence and still doing chemo now. My cancer was not caught early, yet I have been Ned for almost 3 years. Why? I was lucky, I responded well to treatment. If you talk to other long term survivors on these boards, they will tell you the same thing. It is a crap shoot. There are some women who are long term Ned on the her2 site, like 10 - 15 years, and neither one of them had their cancer caught early. One had it in multiple spots, including the brain, and the other had her liver covered in mets. Yet, here they are still Ned while I am sure they have seen many women in the last 10 years who " caught their mets early" yet still died a few years later.

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2013 07:24AM Lauriesh wrote: I try to eat as clean as possible. Because I had liver mets, I don't drink alcohol and try to avoid foods that are  bad for the liver, such as trans fats, food dyes, excess sugar, etc. I try to eat lots of fruits and vegetables, lean protein, whole grains, good fats and a little low fat dairy, usually greek yogurt and low fat cheese. I drink only water. I also don't feel guilty when I splurge. I try to eat healthy 80% of the time, but will have cake on my b-day, cookies at x-mas, etc.  I do believe that diet can make a difference. I know I have said this before on here, but there was a time when drs didn't believe that diet played a role in heart disease or diebetes, and now it is widely accepted that the majority of cases (not all) are diet/exercise related. I just can't imagine that diet can play such a huge role in these and other diseases, yet somehow plays no role in cancer. There is now a lot of evidence about the role of vit d and cancer, and I think in time they will find more connections between diet and cancer. Laurie

Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2012 07:53AM Lauriesh wrote: This had recently been posted on the Her2 support board, so I thought I would repost it here for those who may not have seen it. For those of us that are Her2+, it is very encouraging.  From Annals of Oncology Ann Oncol. 2012 Jul 5. [Epub ahead of print] Durable complete response following chemotherapy and trastuzumab for metastatic HER2-positive breast cancer G. Gullo1,*, M. Zuradelli2, F. Sclafani1, A. Santoro2 and J. Crown1 + Author Affiliations 1Department of Oncology, St Vincent's University Hospital, Dublin, Ireland; 2Oncology and Haematology Unit, Humanitas Cancer Center, Rozzano, Italy ↵*(E-mail: g.gullo@svuh.ie) Individual cases of prolonged complete response (CR) of HER2-positive metastatic breast cancer (MBC) have been reported following treatment with trastuzumab/chemotherapy, but the frequency of durable remission is unknown [1, 2]. We carried out a retrospective study of long-term outcome of all patients with HER2-positive MBC treated in our institutions with chemotherapy and trastuzumab before March 2007. All patients had histology-proven, HER2-positive (3+ on immunohistochemistry and/or HER2/neu gene amplification on FISH) breast cancer. None had received adjuvant trastuzumab. Eighty-four patients were treated from May 2000 to March 2007 (Table 1). Thirteen (15%) achieved CR as defined according to RECIST 1.0 criteria [3]. As part of different institutional practices, patients in Dublin continued on trastuzumab until progression or at least for five years. In Milan trastuzumab was generally stopped in CR patients within two years of achieving remission. As of March 17, 2012, (median follow up 7 years, range 2.5-11.8 years), six of these patients remain alive and continuously cancer free at 142, 139, 122, 101, 84, and 84 months. Two additional patients are alive and continuously free of metastatic cancer at 107 and 105 months, having received curative locoregional therapy for new primary breast cancers. Five patients who achieved CR have developed relapsed MBC, at 44, 37, 35, 30, and 15 months, two while receiving maintenance trastuzumab (at 44 and 37 months, respectively). Three others had discontinued trastuzumab (21, 8, and 4 months after cessation). View this table: In this window In a new window Table 1. Characteristics of patients All of the eight DCR patients received trastuzumab together with their first chemotherapy for metastatic disease. Five (63%) DCR patients had estrogen receptor (ER) negative disease, and five had metastases limited to liver. All but one received a taxane-containing regimen with trastuzumab (docetaxel and carboplatin-4 and single agent taxane-3). The median duration of trastuzumab for CR patients in the two institutions was 67 months (range: 49 to 107+) in Dublin and 14 months (range 5-26) in Milan. Interestingly, although the frequency of CR was very similar in the two institutions (Milan 16% and Dublin 15%), the proportion of patients with DCR was higher in Dublin than Milan (11% versus 6%, respectively), prompting speculation that the duration of trastuzumab therapy might be important. This is the first reported series of long-term follow-up of patients with HER2-positive MBC who achieved CR following chemotherapy and trastuzumab. Our data suggest that a meaningful minority of patients achieve very prolonged complete remissions. Although the small numbers and the retrospective nature of the study preclude definitive statistics, the data also suggest that the impact of trastuzumab might be greater in patients with ER-negative disease (14% DCR-an observation consistent with trials conducted in earlier stage disease [4, 5]) and possibly in those with metastases confined to the liver. Furthermore, the complete absence of DCR among patients who received trastuzumab with their second or subsequent chemotherapy for metastatic disease suggests that this agent should be a component of initial treatment. For patients with ER-negative disease who received trastuzumab with first line chemotherapy, the DCR rate is 16%. At present we are conducting a comprehensive molecular and cytogenetic study of these patients' tumor samples to identify a subset of patients with HER2-positive MBC who are more likely to achieve DCR following chemotherapy plus trastuzumab. We hypothesize that overtly HER2-positive MBC may be a potentially curable disease. Laurie

( I also did a year of tykerb, that first year I was ned, and had so many side effects, I had to stop. Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2014 07:25PM Lauriesh wrote: Mon, Something to keep in mind is that staying on herceptin and perjeta , even when Ned, is now the standard of care.  So someone diagnosed 6 months who is now Ned, will remain on h& p indefinitely. Drs are relying on studies that show there is a benefit of being on both the drugs at the same time ( they work synergistically ).  If they thought that it was best to save perjeta until a woman failed on herceptin, they wouldn't be giving both at the same time to newly diagnosed . I read an article by a Harvard researcher who was disagreeing with the method of staying on one targeted therapy until it failed, and then going on to the next. He believed that it was best to use 2 or even 3 at the same time, as you are hitting different mutations at the same time, and it increases the chances of killing all the cancer cells. Don't know if his theory is right, but to me, it is worth a try. I also did a year of her/ tykerb,  and after reading the Harvard researchers theory, I am really glad that I did. Laurie

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2013 08:32AM - edited Apr 2, 2013 08:33AM by Lauriesh wayne, you are wrong that chemo doesn't kill tumors. I was diagnosed almost 3 years ago with a large, 11 cm liver tumor. If I would not have done chemo, I would have had at the most, 6 months, as my cancer was agressive and it was already affecting my liver functions. I did chemo for 6 months, and while it was difficult, I continued to function pretty normally through it.  The liver tumor is gone and I have now been in remission for 2 years. I am 45 and have 3 kids, 15 ,13 and 10.  Because of chemo, I have had 3 years of birthdays, christmases, easters, vacations. I have seen my oldest start high school and my youngest will start middle school next year. Tell my kids that chemo is a waste of time and never works. I know that the cancer may come back, but I also know that  3-6 % of mbc patients have normal life spans after going into remission.  I hope I am one of them, but even if I am not, I have had 3 wonderful years with my kids that I would have never had if it wasn't for chemo. I am not "one in a million", there are other women on this site with similar situations. there are some that have been in remission for 8 years, five years, etc who all benefitted from chemo. Laurie

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2014 04:49AM - edited Feb 7, 2014 04:50AM by Lauriesh I have a self funded plan through my dh's work and it has been wonderful.  As Sonny said, the administering company makes the original decision, and handles the appeals, but the final say is with his employer. When I was starting tykerb (off label), they denied it. I filed an appeal, but in the meantime, my dh went and spoke with the plan adminstrator at his work. He assured my dh that if the appeal was denied, they would cover it. He told my dh "don't worry, your wife will get any drugs that she needs".  About 2 days later, I got a call that they would cover the tykerb. About 6 months ago, I started perjeta (off label). I was expecting another denial (and so was my onc, as it is such an expensive drug) and they covered it, with no problem. I have never had a scan denied, even when I was early stage. The administering company is Medica, and I think it really varies company by company. I have spoken to reps from medica who commented that my dh's company has a really good plan. My dh always jokes that he gets paid crap, but he is only  there for the ins. Hopefully you have as good an experience as we have had. Laurie

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2012 07:24AM Lauriesh wrote: I think before you criticize everything that has not been proven as being worthless, it is important to remember how science changes over time. For example, if 10 years ago a woman had said that her alt dr told her she should sit out in the sun every day for 30 minutes, you would have criticized her that she was crazy, how would that possibly help her. We now know there is a link between low vitamin d levels and breast cancer. My dr ( a reg onc, not an alt dr) now regularly tests patients for vitamin d and treats aggressively, with prescription doses, those women who are difficient. You would probably criticize someone who says she tries to buy organic natural products, to avoid environmental toxins, as none has been conclusively proven to cause breast cancer. Yet, I recently saw an article on the her2 support site where large concentrations of parabens have been found in breast tissue of women who have breast cancer. Does this prove that it causes cancer or removing them from our products could help us with cancer, no it doesn't. Will science find a concrete link someday, they may, just as they found a link between asbestos and mesothelioma. I am sure you would criticize someone who is using meditation or guided imagery to help fight their cancer. Right? That's crazy, isn't it. Did you see a recent study from Harvard where over 20% of people taking a placebo had improvements in their depression. A researcher had commented "that some studies have suggested that people's beliefs about their therapy play a key role in whether they get better" So, while it is not scientifically proven, yet, that our mind can play a role in healing us, it is not a reason to dismiss the possibility or criticize those who think it might help. How about the Kanzius machine. I am sure if you read about a machine that could cure cancer, you would have laughed. How is stupid is that, right? Well, it showed enough promise that it is now being tested at MD Anderson. I don't believe in a conspiracy theory, that there is a cure out there that is being kept from us,but I do keep an open mind. I take supplements that may have some benefit, such as curcumin, even though it has not been conclusively proven to help fight breast cancer. Science continually changes and i think you are being short sighted if you dismiss everything that is "alternative" as being worthless and a waste of money. Laurie

Posts.Content: Lauriesh wrote: Ok, so I know that tumor markers  are only reliable about 50% of the time, and a lot of oncs don't even use them.  I have had them done routinely since I diagnosed in 2005. When I was initially diagnosed in 2005, stage 2 until March, 2010, my number always fluctuated between 9 and 11. (ca27/29)  When my liver mets were found in July, 2010, it had jumped to 50.  After a few rounds of chemo, it dropped to 26, then continued to drop. I am now NED and I am back at 9.  Everyone is so happy- onc, chemo nurse, family, as if the 9 means that the cancer is gone. I feel that that is not the case, that having this low number doesn't really matter. Don't get me wrong, I know I would rather have a low number than a high number, but that prognosis wise it means very little. That my risk of it coming back is probably the same as someone who has a tm of 50 or 150. Anybody else have a really low number? Are you NED, stable or have active mets? Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2014 03:15AM - edited Jan 10, 2014 03:18AM by Lauriesh stage 4 ned is not the same as stage 2 ned. I asked my onc this, as when I was early stage every year that I was ned, he would tell me that my risk of recurrence was getting lower (this is true for er/pr-, I know it is a little different if your er/pr+) He said this was not true now that I am stage 4.  The risk that the cancer will come back is very high, and even if I am ned for 5 or 7 or 10 years, the risk is very high.  At first I didn't want to believe him, but then there is a woman on the Her2 support site who was ned for like 6 or 7 years on Herceptin. she decided to stop and about 6 months later, the cancer returned to her liver. I thought that really confirmed what my onc was saying.  A related question I have and I have asked 4 oncs and I stumped them all, is "how are the cancer cells that are now floating in my body any different from the cells that were floating in my body in 2008?"  I was diagnosed stage 2 in 2005, and finished my year of herceptin in 2006 and was on no further treatment. There were cancer cells that were in me but yet had not metastatized until 2010.  I had had pet scans in 2008 and 2009 that were clear, so I know the mets weren't there all along. the only onc that could tell me any difference that he knows of, is one from Mayo that I saw , that said that the cells that are now floating in me, are not only resistant to AC, taxol and Herceptin, but now resistant to taxotere, carboplatin, tykerb and Herceptin. All of the other oncs just sort of shrugged their shoulders and couldn't give me any concrete differences between them.   Laurie

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2012 03:28PM - edited Jan 31, 2012 03:28PM by Lauriesh Hi , I'm Laurie. I found BCO when I was diagnosed stage 2 in 2005. I was diagnosed with liver mets in July, 2010. I did 6 rounds of taxotere/Herceptin, then had RFA (radiofrequency ablation) in Feb,2011. I then continued on Herceptin/tykerb until I started a vaccine trial in Seattle in Oct,2011. I go tomorrow for my last visit, then will be starting back on tykerb/Herceptin when I get back. I will be one year NED in a few weeks. I am 44 and have a great husband and 3 kids. Two boys that are 13 and 12 and a little girl that is 9.  We love to travel and just hang out as a family, swimming, playing board games, watching movies and bowling. Before I had kids, I worked as an attorney. I was a stay at home mom for many years, and also worked part of the time as a child advocate. What I like best about this forum is what apple said, it gives me hope! Laurie

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2014 08:08AM Lauriesh wrote: I developed lymphadema in my leg after being on taxotere for 6 months. Luckily I had been seeing a therapist for my arm so she helped me with my leg. I would try to find a certified lymphadema therapist who can do manual lymphatic drainage. She would show you how to wrap and would fit you for compression garments. In the meantime, I would definitely wear the compression socks that you have.  Eat a low sodium diet, drink lots of water, get some exercise, keep it elevated when sitting ( it should be higher than your heart) and  try not to stand for long periods of time without breaks . Laurie
Posts.Title: Lymphodema in the leg springwatch bhd1

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2011 10:55AM Lauriesh wrote: I have had lymphadema in my arm for about 6 years, and it is important to also eat a low sodium diet.  If I have a meal with a lot of sodium, I will pay for it later.  Also, drink a lot of water and do faithfully, any exercises that the therapist reccomends.  I remember when I was first diagnosed with the lymphadema, it seemed overwhelming- all the bandaging, sleeves, massage, exercises etc.   but, you can get it under control.  I rarely bandage anymore and don't wear my complession garments either.  Your right about the weather. any flareup I have is always on a really hot and humid day. Laurie

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2014 08:50AM - edited Jul 15, 2014 09:13AM by Lauriesh I think the problem is that the term " remission" is really not used as a medical term anymore. I have been Ned for 3 1/2 years and all of the drs I see have never used that word. My onc, when discussing my scans uses the term " disease free"  . I use the term remission when I post on caringbridge or talking to friends and family because that is the term they are familiar with. I agree with divine that remission is not associated with cured. I think that is why that term was probably first used, to clarify that the person is not cured, they are only in remission. I think that most people,in the general public,  if you asked them what it meant to be in remission, woud say that there are no signs of cancer right now. Exactly what Ned means also. I think I know who you are talking about and I guess I have no problem with what she is saying.  While I don't say it out loud, I hope I  am in that 2-5 % that " may be cured" also.  Who wouldn't? I think getting to Ned is the first step in having a chance of being in that small % who live a normal lifespan and I think that is what she is celebrating . Laurie

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2011 07:24AM Lauriesh wrote: Hi lilylady, I first wanted to mention that there is a site called her2support.org. There are several women on that site who have had liver resections, and there is a current discussion going on as a couple of women had their surgeries this week. I had two liver tumors, with the largest being 11 cm. I had chemo, than rfa. I was diagnosed almost a year ago, and have read all I could about resection, rfa and other options.  I think it is strange that they are talking about doing a resection, but not removing  all of the cancer from the liver.  I have never read of someone that had a resection that wasn't going to remove all of the cancer (or at least what the scans can show) from the liver.  some concerns I would have is how long would you have to be off chemo after the resection? Since you still have other sites of cancer, wouldn't it be a risk to stop chemo? I would also ask if you are a candidate for rfa. It is a much easier procedure (outpatient) with a much easier recovery.  I was told that if I had a resection, I would be in the hospital for 4 days, with at least 6 weeks for a full recovery. If I were you, I would go for a second opinion. I went to two large cancer centers, and got two very different reccomendations.       Laurie

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2011 09:38AM - edited Oct 30, 2011 10:16AM by Lauriesh I also agree with coolbreeze.  I don't mind the posts asking for help with treatment advice,  but I just hate reading the ones where caregivers give blow by blow descriptions of their relatives dying or the pain that they are experiencing.  I can't help but think of my husband and kids and know that the day is coming that they will be going through that.  I do think it is strange, again not the ones asking what chemo might be best etc. , but the ones asking for emotional support to be asking support from people who are dealing with so much themselves.  It just seems that going to the other forum, where they can ask other family members for support seems more reasonable than asking us. I do also think it is insensitive. I lost my mother to cancer (not breast) and I would have never went on a site dedicated to stage 4 people fighting for their lives, and post the details of my mother's death or ask how I am going to live without her, I am so devasted, etc. and then expect these people to console me or give me advice of how to move on, etc. When people on this board respond to these posts, it's usually based on being a caregiver for a family member. They could post this same type of post on the stage 1 & 2 forum and get similar responses. Laurie

Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2013 08:30AM Lauriesh wrote: For me, it as gotten a little better over time. I guess I gauge that by how many ativans I have to take around scan time. I have been Ned for almost 2 1/2 years and at my last scan in may, I only had to take 1, the morning I was waiting for the call with the results . I am getting better at blocking out the what ifs, and just staying in the moment. I keep busy, doing fun things and not so fun things ( I realized my house is always the cleanest when it is scan time, my dh would probably like it if I had scans more than just twice a year.) I had a cousin, who was 42 and healthy, die suddenly of cardiac arrest. No warning, no good bye to his wife and kids. I think about him a lot when I begin stressing out and remind myself to enjoy this day, this moment . I was seeing a therapist for awhile and she told me to focus on the saying " today I am healthy and cancer free ". And yeah, we know that it is not completely true, that there are probably cancer cells floating through our body, but sitting in a quiet spot and repeating that phrase does help me calm down and stay in the moment, instead of the what ifs and worry. Laurie

Posts.Content: Nov 13, 2010 08:23AM Lauriesh wrote: Hi Anne,  I had a Diep flap at NOLA in 2006 , after I was initially diagnosed stage 2 in 2005.   It is a MAJOR surgery with a long recovery. The dr.s are great and I felt like I was in good hands, but it took a good 3 months to recover. I was 38 at the time and in excellent health (on no meds and a year out from any treatments)  If I was facing this as a stage 4, as I am now, I personally would not have the surgery. I would have implants. If you have more questions about NOLA or the procedure, feel free to pm me. Laurie
